Roshan Dathathri	Adaptive Scheduler for LLM Inference Request Routing and Migration	Systems & Networking 	Inference 2030	Current LLM inference workloads include tool usage (with system prompts)
column3: and application-specific user level prompts. LLM inference workloads are characterized by unpredictability of request processing time both due to dynamic response lengths and due to the KV cache state that could be reused across requests. Reusing the KV cache for previously seen prompts avoids recomputing the KV cache
column4: thereby providing better performance. The potential KV cache reuse over requests is affected by how long the KV cache can stay in the GPU memory before being evicted by incoming requests. To meet the guarantees of SLA attainment of such workloads coupled with unpredictable arrival rates
column5: current pools are typically over-provisioned with multiple replicas serving the same model. This may lead to resource-underutilization. Prior pool-level schedulers assume a static prioritization of KV-cache-hit versus load balancing. Prioritizing KV-cache-hit over load balancing may hurt tail latency. In this project
column6: we build a pool-level scheduler that dynamically adapts based on the current workload and resource characteristics while ensuring SLA attainment
column8: and/or low energy usage. We also eagerly offload the KV cache to a memory server shared among replicas
column9: which enables novel performance optimizations including migrating failed requests to new serving replicas with minimal disruption. 	aashakashah

column1: Abhinav Jangda	Exploring and Automating Novel Optimizations for GPU Matrix Multiplication Kernels using LLMs	Programming Languages & Software Engineering	Inference 2030	"GPU based MatMul (Matrix Multiplication) kernels are central to large scale AI systems
column3: optimizing these MatMul kernels can decrease time
column6: one of the critical services provided by Microsoft. Existing MatMul kernels implement the classic O(n3) algorithm; however
column7: it has been shown that other algorithms
column10: have lower algorithmic complexity of O(n2.81). Despite these theoretical improvements
column11: it is extremely difficult to implement these algorithms in practice due to their irregular and recursive nature
column12: which are not well suited for GPU programming models. In this poster/demo
column13: we present the first highly optimized MatMul implementation (for both single-precision and mixed-precision) using the Strassen algorithm for NVIDIA GPUs. For the critical MatMul kernels found in several popular LLMs (including Llama 3 and Qwen 3-32b)
column14: our FP16 Tensor Core implementation runs up to 12% faster than NVIDIA’s optimized kernels.

column1: Writing the above optimized Strassen MatMul kernels took several months of tedious manual programming effort
column2: requiring detailed knowledge of low-level architecture features of NVIDIA GPUs. To aid in such development
column3: we have been developing GPUGenie: an LLM-based GPU kernel optimizer. GPUGenie has a knowledge base of GPU kernel optimizations (written in natural language and easily extensible) and then utilizes this knowledge to iteratively transform (optimize) a GPU kernel. After transformation
column4: GPUGenie automatically validates and profiles the kernel
column5: providing a detailed report to the kernel developer. Currently
column6: GPUGenie can apply complex MatMul kernel optimizations resulting in kernels that are competitive with NVIDIA’s hand optimized kernels. We plan to extend GPUGenie to more complex optimizations
column7: such as the ones that are required for Strassen algorithm
column9: automating the optimization of performance critical GPU kernels that drive important Microsoft services."	ajangda

column1: Gabriel Ebner	Proofs à la Carte: Verified Code with Pulse	Programming Languages & Software Engineering	Programming Languages/Software	"Across the company and the industry
column2: large codebases continue to be written in memory-unsafe languages.  Even code in memory-safe languages is susceptible to security-critical bugs such as buffer reuse or malleability issues.  Pulse is our answer to secure this critical attack surface: a modern
column3: concurrent separation logic that enables scalable and modular proofs of memory safety and optionally functional correctness.

column1: On top of Pulse
column2: we are building tools that bring verification in a production-ready package:

column1: •	EverParse is a toolchain to automatically generate provably memory-safe and secure binary parsers and serializers
column2: and is replacing hand-written unsafe parsers in CoreOS

column1: •	Kuiper is a library for writing generic
column2: memory-safe and data race-free GPU kernels without sacrificing performance
column3: natively supporting low-level atomics and barriers.

column1: •	C2Pulse is an annotation framework that brings memory-safety to existing C code
column2: without requiring costly and risky rewrites in a different language.

column1: We have ongoing engagements with several teams in CoreOS

column1: Sergio Valcarcel Macua	SmartReplay: AI agents for gameplay testing	AI Agents (Interactive
column5: video game testing is critical to ensuring high quality titles. However
column6: gameplay testing is hard and costly
column7: since games are arbitrarily complex worlds that have to be played in real time
column8: and standard scripting-based automation can be very time consuming and not always possible due to stochastic game elements. In the SmartReplay project
column9: we are developing insights and technology for agents capable of learning to solve complex tasks in rich stochastic environments from few demonstrations. We are focused on retail requirements
column10: so the technology can be more easily adopted in different scenarios
column11: from certification to game development to hardware testing
column12: etc. Our agents learn from video input only
column13: operate the full Xbox controller in real-time. Moreover
column14: our approach is game agnostic and can be applied to any game!	clovett

column1: Sarah Parisot	Real-Time Text-Conditioned World Models for Interactive Prototyping	AI/ML Foundations	AI ML Foundations	"Recent advances in world models have enabled the generation of gameplay sequences that respond to user input
column2: opening up exciting possibilities for creative applications such as rapid prototyping of game ideas. Yet
column3: these models often fall short of real-time interactivity and struggle to produce novel content beyond their training environments.

column1: In this work
column2: we take early steps toward unlocking the full creative potential of world models
column5: and more controllable. Building on our previous work
column7: we introduce a new modelling approach that replaces next-token prediction with discrete diffusion
column8: enabling significant speed-ups with minimal loss in output quality.

column1: We explore how new game behaviours can be learned and triggered at inference time in a controlled manner. To this end
column2: we introduce text to control the game environment generated by the model
column3: and curate the BodySwap dataset which simulates a character swapping mechanism
column4: allowing to change the playable character on the fly.

column1: This proof-of-concept highlights the potential of world models as powerful tools for interactive prototyping and user content generation
column2: made possible through intentional data curation and efficient fine-tuning. Our work lays the foundation for real-time
column3: user-driven experimentation in game design and beyond."	"Raluca Stevenson (rageorg)

column2: allowing humans and machines to hear not just what happens
column3: but where. The demo combines two recent research projects:

column1: 1) a codec that converts a four-channel microphone signal to discrete tokens
2) a multimodal small language model that understands and reasons over spatial audio tokens.
The demo demonstrates how machines can not only recognize what is being heard
column2: but also infer and reason over where sounds occur in a 3D environment."	hagamper

Roshan Dathathri	Adaptive Scheduler for LLM Inference Request Routing and Migration	Systems & Networking 	Inference 2030	Current LLM inference workloads include tool usage (with system prompts)
column3: and application-specific user level prompts. LLM inference workloads are characterized by unpredictability of request processing time both due to dynamic response lengths and due to the KV cache state that could be reused across requests. Reusing the KV cache for previously seen prompts avoids recomputing the KV cache
column4: thereby providing better performance. The potential KV cache reuse over requests is affected by how long the KV cache can stay in the GPU memory before being evicted by incoming requests. To meet the guarantees of SLA attainment of such workloads coupled with unpredictable arrival rates
column5: current pools are typically over-provisioned with multiple replicas serving the same model. This may lead to resource-underutilization. Prior pool-level schedulers assume a static prioritization of KV-cache-hit versus load balancing. Prioritizing KV-cache-hit over load balancing may hurt tail latency. In this project
column6: we build a pool-level scheduler that dynamically adapts based on the current workload and resource characteristics while ensuring SLA attainment
column8: and/or low energy usage. We also eagerly offload the KV cache to a memory server shared among replicas
column9: which enables novel performance optimizations including migrating failed requests to new serving replicas with minimal disruption. 	aashakashah

column1: Abhinav Jangda	Exploring and Automating Novel Optimizations for GPU Matrix Multiplication Kernels using LLMs	Programming Languages & Software Engineering	Inference 2030	"GPU based MatMul (Matrix Multiplication) kernels are central to large scale AI systems
column3: optimizing these MatMul kernels can decrease time
column6: one of the critical services provided by Microsoft. Existing MatMul kernels implement the classic O(n3) algorithm; however
column7: it has been shown that other algorithms
column10: have lower algorithmic complexity of O(n2.81). Despite these theoretical improvements
column11: it is extremely difficult to implement these algorithms in practice due to their irregular and recursive nature
column12: which are not well suited for GPU programming models. In this poster/demo
column13: we present the first highly optimized MatMul implementation (for both single-precision and mixed-precision) using the Strassen algorithm for NVIDIA GPUs. For the critical MatMul kernels found in several popular LLMs (including Llama 3 and Qwen 3-32b)
column14: our FP16 Tensor Core implementation runs up to 12% faster than NVIDIA’s optimized kernels.

column1: Writing the above optimized Strassen MatMul kernels took several months of tedious manual programming effort
column2: requiring detailed knowledge of low-level architecture features of NVIDIA GPUs. To aid in such development
column3: we have been developing GPUGenie: an LLM-based GPU kernel optimizer. GPUGenie has a knowledge base of GPU kernel optimizations (written in natural language and easily extensible) and then utilizes this knowledge to iteratively transform (optimize) a GPU kernel. After transformation
column4: GPUGenie automatically validates and profiles the kernel
column5: providing a detailed report to the kernel developer. Currently
column6: GPUGenie can apply complex MatMul kernel optimizations resulting in kernels that are competitive with NVIDIA’s hand optimized kernels. We plan to extend GPUGenie to more complex optimizations
column7: such as the ones that are required for Strassen algorithm
column9: automating the optimization of performance critical GPU kernels that drive important Microsoft services."	ajangda

column1: Gabriel Ebner	Proofs à la Carte: Verified Code with Pulse	Programming Languages & Software Engineering	Programming Languages/Software	"Across the company and the industry
column2: large codebases continue to be written in memory-unsafe languages.  Even code in memory-safe languages is susceptible to security-critical bugs such as buffer reuse or malleability issues.  Pulse is our answer to secure this critical attack surface: a modern
column3: concurrent separation logic that enables scalable and modular proofs of memory safety and optionally functional correctness.

column1: On top of Pulse
column2: we are building tools that bring verification in a production-ready package:

column1: •	EverParse is a toolchain to automatically generate provably memory-safe and secure binary parsers and serializers
column2: and is replacing hand-written unsafe parsers in CoreOS

column1: •	Kuiper is a library for writing generic
column2: memory-safe and data race-free GPU kernels without sacrificing performance
column3: natively supporting low-level atomics and barriers.

column1: •	C2Pulse is an annotation framework that brings memory-safety to existing C code
column2: without requiring costly and risky rewrites in a different language.

column1: We have ongoing engagements with several teams in CoreOS

column1: Sergio Valcarcel Macua	SmartReplay: AI agents for gameplay testing	AI Agents (Interactive
column5: video game testing is critical to ensuring high quality titles. However
column6: gameplay testing is hard and costly
column7: since games are arbitrarily complex worlds that have to be played in real time
column8: and standard scripting-based automation can be very time consuming and not always possible due to stochastic game elements. In the SmartReplay project
column9: we are developing insights and technology for agents capable of learning to solve complex tasks in rich stochastic environments from few demonstrations. We are focused on retail requirements
column10: so the technology can be more easily adopted in different scenarios
column11: from certification to game development to hardware testing
column12: etc. Our agents learn from video input only
column13: operate the full Xbox controller in real-time. Moreover
column14: our approach is game agnostic and can be applied to any game!	clovett

column1: Sarah Parisot	Real-Time Text-Conditioned World Models for Interactive Prototyping	AI/ML Foundations	AI ML Foundations	"Recent advances in world models have enabled the generation of gameplay sequences that respond to user input
column2: opening up exciting possibilities for creative applications such as rapid prototyping of game ideas. Yet
column3: these models often fall short of real-time interactivity and struggle to produce novel content beyond their training environments.

column1: In this work
column2: we take early steps toward unlocking the full creative potential of world models
column5: and more controllable. Building on our previous work
column7: we introduce a new modelling approach that replaces next-token prediction with discrete diffusion
column8: enabling significant speed-ups with minimal loss in output quality.

column1: We explore how new game behaviours can be learned and triggered at inference time in a controlled manner. To this end
column2: we introduce text to control the game environment generated by the model
column3: and curate the BodySwap dataset which simulates a character swapping mechanism
column4: allowing to change the playable character on the fly.

column1: This proof-of-concept highlights the potential of world models as powerful tools for interactive prototyping and user content generation
column2: made possible through intentional data curation and efficient fine-tuning. Our work lays the foundation for real-time
column3: user-driven experimentation in game design and beyond."	"Raluca Stevenson (rageorg)
